results.name: How the astronomical clock ("Orloj") in Prague would strike 1,2,3,...,24,25,.. (digits follow 12343212343... (A028356), n-th group adds to n).
comment: This remarkable sequence is really a sequence of lists rather than numbers.
reference: Zdenek Horsky, "Prazsky Orloj" ["The Astronomical Clock of Prague", in Czech], Panorama, Prague, 1988, pp. 76-78.
link: Seiichi Manyama, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..2500
Michal Krížek, Alena Šolcová and Lawrence Somer, Construction of Šindel sequences, Comment. Math. Univ. Carolin., 48 (2007), 373-388.
N. J. A. Sloane, My favorite integer sequences, in Sequences and their Applications (Proceedings of SETA '98).
mathematica: n[k_] := For[n0 = m[k] + 1, True, n0++, If[Sum[s[i], {i, m[k] + 1, n0}] == k, Return[n0]]];
a[k_] := a[k] = Table[s[i], {i, m[k] + 1, n[k]}] // FromDigits; Array[a, 27] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Mar 14 2016 *)
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, _J. H. Conway_
